ygData.msgSnippet: I would be very suspicious of trying to calculate any equilibrium property when a reaction that is treated as irreversible is included in the reaction

I would be very suspicious of trying to calculate any equilibrium  
property when a reaction that is treated as irreversible is included  
in the reaction mechanism.  You should first check that all species  
production rates are zero when the gas mole fractions are the  
equilibrium values for the computed T and P. By definition, the  
adiabatic flame temperature is the temperature achieved at  
equilibrium, at fixed enthalpy and pressure, with equilibrium mole  
fractions.  But of course chemistry may make the mole fractions  
strong functions of temperature, so the partitioning of energy among  
different forms will result in the sensible energy component  
(proportional to temperature) changing strongly wih T.  In any case,  
using global irreversible kinetic rate laws never works near  
equilibrium. If it works at all, it would be for situations far from  
equilibrium, such as in the unburned gases.

No global reaction mechanism with non-integral stoichiometric  
coefficients is accurate outside the range of parameters for which it  
was fit.  If the mechanism was determined by fitting to ignition  
data, for example, then it may be useful to interpret other ignition  
problems too (or maybe not, hard to say), but it absolutely cannot be  
used to simulate very different procsses. Th only way to achieve a  
robust simulation of a flame is to include all of the important  
elemenary reactions, and model all reactions s raaeversible (which  
every elementary reaction in fact is
The only way to accurately compute flame speeds is to use reaction  
mechanisms with multiple (perhaps hundreds) of elementary reactions,  
the rate of each of which obeys mass-action kinetics and is  
reversible.  But this is easy with Cantera - it does all of the hard  
work for you.  See for example the Python demos under "flames."

Hope this helps,
Dave


On Feb 15, 2008, at 2:44 AM, benedetta.franzelli wrote:

>
> Hi!!
> I have already solved this problem. For 1step-reaction CH4 + 2 O2 =>
> CO2 + 2 H2O is sufficient to modifie the orders of the reaction in the
> .cti file. Now, i'm trying to perform a 1D premixed flame with a 2step
> reaction:
> 1) CH4 +1.5 02 => CO +2 H2O, Arrhenius parameters=[0.6000E+16, 0.0,
> 35000], order="CH4:0.9 O2:1.10 "
> 2) CO + 0.5 O2 <=> CO2, Arrhenius parametr=[0.2E+10, 0.0, 12000].
> In this case it is not sufficent to change the order of the reaction
> to achieve some good results. Actually, the method is convergent but,
> even if the adiabatic temperature and the mole fractions of the
> species are correct, the speed flame is completly wrong. I can't find
> where is the problem. I hope to have benn sufficiently clear.
> Thanks for any helps
> Benedetta
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "benedetta.franzelli"
> <benedetta.franzelli@...> wrote:
>>
>> Hi..I would like to use Cantera to study air_Methane combustion  
>> with 1
>> step mechanisme; i.e.    CH4 + 2 O2 => CO2 + 2 H2O .
>> The progress rate Q is: Q = Kf  Prod_{k=1}^{N} | X k | ^nk'
>> - Kr  Prod_{k=1}^{N} | X k | ^nk''
>> where Kf e Kr are the forward and reverse rates of reaction, n is the
>> number of species, | X k | are the molar concentrations. The forward
>> rate of reaction is modeled using the Arrhenius law and modifing the
>> .cti file. But I can't find how to set with Cantera the values of nk'
>> and nk'' and the number of Schimdt for each species. Is it  
>> possible  to
>> work with 1/2 step mechanisme??
>>
>> Thanks for your attention,
>> Benedetta
